edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:00): but I'm the teacher now, or something :p
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:16): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I wish there were a count of the number of pages using xmlns attributes instead of just count of attributes
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:16): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: Which file are you looking at?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:17): oops, my paste failed
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:17): http://philip.html5.org/data/xmlns-bindings.txt
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:17): actually, I'm not even sure what those counts are
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:17): are they counts of the number of times that prefix declaration appeared, or the number of pages on which it appeared?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:17): "Counts are the number of pages with that attribute name+value."
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:18): so number of pages
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:18): http://philip.html5.org/data/xmlns-attributes.txt is similar but newer
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:19): (though it includes non-HTML pages too, I think)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:20): what I'm curious about that I don't think I can get from this output is the number of pages that contain at least one xmlns attribute
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:20): in your older study, 79% of the occurrences of namespace declarations had "microsoft" in the namespace URI
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:20): Do you mean xmlns:* (i.e. not counting xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml")?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:20): that seems less likely with the new data
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:22): (also of potential interest would be a separate count of xmlns= that are neither the xhtml namespace URI nor empty, if there are nay such)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:22): I could upload my list of all (url, element-name, attribute-name-which-begins-with-"xmlns", attribute-value) from the dotbot data so you can process it yourself, if you want
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:24): that would be neat
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:24): http://philip.html5.org/data/xmlns-attributes-raw.txt.bz2 (~5MB)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:25): (with all the usual caveats about sample selections and bias and bugs and so on)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:33): $ grep 'xmlns:' xmlns-attributes-raw.txt | sed -e 's/    *//g;' | sort | uniq | xwc -l
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:34): Your sed looks wrong
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:34): They're tab-separated fields
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:34): I used a tab
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:34): (use ^V to enter a literal tab)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:35): by that count, 4.4% of pages contain an XML namespace prefix declaration
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:35): Oh, it looks like spaces in IRC :-)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:35): (I'd use "cut -f1" to extract the first field instead)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:35): I checked that it stripped all fields but the first
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:36): cut -f1 gives a different result so I may have made a mistake
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:36): I get 18718 if I *don't* do any sed/cut
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:37): my sed line is wrong
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:37): (it doesn't do nothing, but it does do the stripping wrong
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:37): Oh, good point
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:37): what I wanted was sed -e 's/    .*//g;', except that cut is better
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:37): It's just stripping out the tabs, I guess
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:38): so 1.8% of pages include at least one XML Namespace prefix declaration
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:39): Is it ok if I put a link to the raw data in the HTML WG wiki?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:40): Note that quite a few of these pages appear to be RSS feeds
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:40): which annoyingly happen to be included in the data set
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:41): doesn't claim that it is high-quality data
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:41): 2476 pages have an xml namespace prefix declaration that has "microsoft" in the namespace URI
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:43): $ grep 'xmlns:' xmlns-attributes-raw.txt | egrep -v 'rss|feed' | cut -f1 | sort | uniq | xwc -l
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:43): $ grep 'xmlns:.*microsoft' xmlns-attributes-raw.txt | egrep -v 'rss|feed' | cut -f1 | sort | uniq | xwc -l
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:44): so more like 1.6%, and 36% of those are Microsoft namespace URIs

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:06): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: the autocomplete=off instances on the facebook homepage are not conformant; autocomplete is explicitly not allowed on input/@type=hidden
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:06): http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/forms.html#hidden-state

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:07): ok, I'll close it myself now

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (15:26): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: question: do you understand the error in the doctype reported here? http://validator.nu/?doc=http%3A%2F%2Ffacebook.com%2F&schema=http%3A%2F%2Fs.validator.nu%2Fhtml5%2Fhtml5full.rnc+http%3A%2F%2Fs.validator.nu%2Fhtml5%2Fassertions.sch+http%3A%2F%2Fc.validator.nu%2Fall%2F
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (15:26): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: it seems to be complaining about the newline - I think
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (15:26): is that actually noncomforming?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (15:28): ok, looks like newlines in the doctype are indeed disallowed in HTML5
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (15:28): is that also true in XML, or SGML?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (15:31): AryehGregor: When talking about blind users, don't forget the ones that *are* measurably important to all authors, the search engines.

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (15:32): AryehGregor: (That is, ironically, why I have to keep *removing* alt text from my company's site, because the idiot SEO people just keep cramming keywords into them.)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:32): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: Newlinwa in doctype appear to be OK per XML
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (15:33): I'm not sure why HTML5 only allows spaces as the whitespace in doctypes
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (15:33): (at least that's what it appears to do)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:44): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: as far as the code that's emitting that error message, it's in the htmlparser code, so I have less insight into to that
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:44): I'm also have no idea why it's disallowed
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:44): I think it may just be a mistake
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:45): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: Why do you think the newline has any effect?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:45): All whitespace should be handled the same, and I don't see any different behaviour here

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (15:46): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: this is an error: http://validator.nu/?doc=http%3A%2F%2Ffacebook.com%2F&schema=http%3A%2F%2Fs.validator.nu%2Fhtml5%2Fhtml5full.rnc+http%3A%2F%2Fs.validator.nu%2Fhtml5%2Fassertions.sch+http%3A%2F%2Fc.validator.nu%2Fall%2F
